sentences.text: The coup's leader Brice Oligui Nguema is part of the Bongo family and overthrew his cousin Ali Bongo. The coup brought an end to the 56-year-long rule of the father-and-son duo Omar and Ali Bongo over Gabon. It has been described by some as a Coup d'état#Palace coup|palace coup.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Faloyin |first=Dipo |date=2023-08-30 |title=A Coup in Gabon Seems to Have Ended One Family's 56-Year Rule |url=https://www.vice.com/en/article/7kxwyb/a-coup-in-gabon-seems-to-have-ended-one-familys-56-year-rule |access-date=2024-05-03 |website=Vice |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Since independence from French colonial empire|France in 1960, Gabon has primarily been ruled by the Bongo family starting with President Omar Bongo in 1967 and, following his death in 2009, by his son Ali Bongo|Ali Bongo Ondimba. Ali Bongo was re-elected in an 2016 Gabonese presidential election|election in 2016 which prompted a failed 2019 Gabonese coup attempt|coup attempt in 2019. During the rule of the Bongo family the country had been plagued by accusations of corruption and nepotism,{{overcite|date=September 2024}} several elections had been tainted by reports of fraud or irregularities (notably, the official results of the 2016 election from the Bongo family's native province of Haut-Ogooué Province|Haut-Ogooué showed Bongo receiving 95.5% of the vote on an alleged 99.9% turnout, an improbable result sparking widespread protests), and the Constitution of Gabon|Constitution and electoral laws had been changed multiple times in order to remove term limits, change the voting system to exploit the fractured opposition, and change the timing of elections to ensure the opposition could not rally following a win by the ruling party.

sentences.text: Despite being a member of OPEC, (which accounts for 60% of national revenue), and having one of the highest per-capita GDPs on the continent, Gabon faces serious socioeconomic crises: a third of the population lives below the poverty line of US$5.50 per day, and the unemployment rate among Gabonese aged 15 to 24 was estimated at 40% in 2020. Gabon was also ranked 136th out of 180 countries for the perception of corruption by Transparency International in 2022.

references.text: <ref name="africa1"/> one of Africa's major producers of oil<ref name="bbc">{{cite news |last1=Wright |first1=George |last2=Armstrong |first2=Kathryn |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon: Army officers say they are taking power |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66654965 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830045955/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66654965 |archive-date=30 August 2023 |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref>

sentences.text: In a speech delivered on the country's Independence Day on 17 August, Bongo, a close ally of France, insisted that he would not allow Gabon to be subjected to "destabilization", referring to other recent coups in the region.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon coup: How did events unfold? |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-military-takeover-how-did-events-unfold/ |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Africanews |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830093901/https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-military-takeover-how-did-events-unfold/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Following 2023 Gabonese general election|presidential elections held on 26 August 2023, the incumbent president, Ali Bongo, who had been seeking re-election for a third term, was declared the winner according to an official announcement made on 30 August. However, allegations of electoral fraud and irregularities immediately emerged from opposition parties and independent observers, casting doubt over the legitimacy of the election results. Among those who criticized the results was Albert Ondo Ossa, who had come second in the elections according to the official count. 2023 Gabonese general election|Parliamentary elections, 2023 Gabonese departmental elections|departmental elections and 2023 Gabonese local elections|local elections were held the same day.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Au Gabon, Ali Bongo réélu président avec 64,27 % des voix |url=https://www.france24.com/fr/info-en-continu/20230830-gabon-ali-bongo-r%C3%A9%C3%A9lu-pr%C3%A9sident-avec-64-27-des-voix-r%C3%A9sultats-officiels |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=France 24 |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830045549/https://www.france24.com/fr/info-en-continu/20230830-gabon-ali-bongo-r%C3%A9%C3%A9lu-pr%C3%A9sident-avec-64-27-des-voix-r%C3%A9sultats-officiels |url-status=live |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon's Ali Bongo re-elected president in disputed election |url=https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20230830-gabon-s-ali-bongo-re-elected-president-in-disputed-election |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=France 24 |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830064122/https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20230830-gabon-s-ali-bongo-re-elected-president-in-disputed-election |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-06-27 |title=Gabon: élections présidentielle, législatives et locales le 26 août |url=https://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/gabon-elections-presidentielle-legislatives-et-locales-le-26-aout-20230627 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230630072613/https://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/gabon-elections-presidentielle-legislatives-et-locales-le-26-aout-20230627 |archive-date=30 June 2023 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=LEFIGARO |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: Just two hours before the polls closed, Ondo Ossa denounced "fraud orchestrated by the Bongo camp". He had already claimed victory and urged Bongo to facilitate a peaceful transfer of power based on his own purported vote count. The official election results were announced in the middle of the night on state television without prior notice. The country was placed under curfew and internet access was cut off throughout the nation, measures implemented by the government to prevent the spread of "false news" and potential violence.

references.text: <ref name="bfm">{{cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon: Ali Bongo réélu pour un 3e mandat, des militaires veulent annuler les résultats |url=https://www.bfmtv.com/international/afrique/gabon-ali-bongo-reelu-pour-un-3e-mandat-des-militaires-veulent-annuler-les-resultats_AD-202308300056.html |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=BFM TV |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830064635/https://www.bfmtv.com/international/afrique/gabon-ali-bongo-reelu-pour-un-3e-mandat-des-militaires-veulent-annuler-les-resultats_AD-202308300056.html |url-status=live |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: Amidst growing scrutiny and widespread protests over the conduct of the elections, the Armed Forces of Gabon launched a pre-dawn coup on 30 August. Soldiers led by high-ranking officers seized control of key government buildings, communication channels, and strategic points within the capital Libreville. Gunfire was also heard in the city.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1696742167438626840|user=AFP|title=#BREAKING 'We are putting an end to the current regime,' Gabon soldiers say on TV|author=Agence France-Presse|date=30 August 2023|access-date=30 August 2023|language=en}}</ref>

<ref name="rfi">{{cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon: après l'annonce de la réélection d'Ali Bongo, des militaires proclament l'annulation du scrutin |url=https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20230830-gabon-ali-bongo-r%C3%A9%C3%A9lu-pour-un-troisi%C3%A8me-mandat |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=Radio France Internationale|RFI |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830064122/https://www.rfi.fr/fr/afrique/20230830-gabon-ali-bongo-r%C3%A9%C3%A9lu-pour-un-troisi%C3%A8me-mandat |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon: coup d'État en cours, les militaires annoncent la fin du régime |url=https://fr.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-coup-detat-en-cours-les-militaires-annoncent-la-fin-du-regime/ |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=africanews |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830064126/https://fr.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-coup-detat-en-cours-les-militaires-annoncent-la-fin-du-regime/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1696740441088233851|user=AFP|title=#BREAKING Gunfire heard in Gabon capital Libreville: @AFP journalists|author=Agence France-Presse|date=30 August 2023|access-date=30 August 2023|language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The coup occurred just minutes after Bongo's re-election was declared at 3:30 am West Africa Time|WAT by the Gabonese Electoral Commission with 64.27% of the vote. During a televised morning address from the Palais du bord de mer|Presidential Palace in Libreville on the state channel Gabon 24, around a dozen military personnel announced the end of the existing regime, with a military spokesperson claiming to be speaking on behalf of a "Committee for the Transition and Restoration of Institutions", citing "irresponsible, unpredictable governance" that had led to "a continuous degradation of social cohesion, risking pushing the country into chaos." They announced the annulment of the recent election, the dissolution of state institutions, Internet access, which had been cut since the election, was reported to have been restored, while the curfew put in place at the time of the election was extended until further notice. but was later shortened to the early morning.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Diekhans |first=Antje |title=Nach Präsidentschaftswahl: Militär stürzt Regierung in Gabun |url=https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/afrika/gabun-militaer-104.html |access-date=30 August 2023 |website=tagesschau |language=de |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830110620/https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/afrika/gabun-militaer-104.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="bfm"/><ref>{{cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Au Gabon, des militaires proclament l'annulation des élections après l'annonce de la victoire d'Ali Bongo |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2023/08/30/au-gabon-ali-bongo-ondimba-reelu-president-avec-64-27-des-suffrages-exprimes_6187021_3212.html |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=Le Monde |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830045603/https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2023/08/30/au-gabon-ali-bongo-ondimba-reelu-president-avec-64-27-des-suffrages-exprimes_6187021_3212.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="rfi"/> and the closure of the country's borders, which were reopened on 2 September.<ref name="border">{{cite news |date=2 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup leader: No rush to elections and 'the same mistakes' |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/2/gabon-coup-leader-no-rush-to-elections-and-the-same-mistakes |access-date=2 September 2023 |publisher=Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera |archive-date=2 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230902154821/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/2/gabon-coup-leader-no-rush-to-elections-and-the-same-mistakes |url-status=live }}</ref>

content.title: Arrests of Ali Bongo and other officials

sentences.text:
, pictured in 2022]] 
The junta later announced the arrest and home detention of Bongo and his eldest son and adviser Noureddin Bongo Valentin, adding that the two were with family and doctors. However, lawyers for Ali Bongo's wife Sylvia Bongo Ondimba|Sylvia Valentin later claimed that Nouredin was being held in an undisclosed location. and was later charged with money laundering, receiving stolen goods, forgery and fraud. The President of the National Assembly of Gabon|National Assembly, Richard Auguste Onouviet, was also arrested by the junta, along with presidential chief of staff Ian Ghislain Ngoulou, his deputy Mohamed Ali Saliou, presidential spokesperson {{ill|Jessye Ella Ekogha|fr}}, another presidential adviser and the two top officials in Bongo's Gabonese Democratic Party (PDG). The junta said that they were arrested on charges that included treason, embezzlement, corruption, falsifying the president's signature and drug-trafficking. Trunks, suitcases and bags filled with billions of Central African CFA francs were reportedly seized from their homes, with Ngoulou claiming that some of the money was part of Bongo’s election fund.<ref name="border"/>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=30 August 2023 |first=Frank |last=Andrews |title=Gabon coup attempt sees military chiefs declare election results "cancelled" and "end to current regime" |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/gabon-coup-attempt-military-officers-say-election-cancelled-west-africa/ |access-date=31 August 2023 |publisher=CBS News |language=en-US |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831010710/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/gabon-coup-attempt-military-officers-say-election-cancelled-west-africa/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="border"/> Valentin herself was reported to be under house arrest,<ref>{{Cite web |date=14 September 2023 |title=Gabon: President Oligui relaunches investigations into public markets |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/14/gabon-president-oligui-relaunches-investigations-into-public-markets/ |access-date=14 September 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=14 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230914184620/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/14/gabon-president-oligui-relaunches-investigations-into-public-markets/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=29 September 2023 |title=Gabon charges wife of ousted president with 'money laundering' |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/29/gabon-charges-wife-of-ousted-president-with-money-laundering/ |access-date=29 September 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bonny |first=Sidonie Aurore |date=31 August 2023 |title=Military in Gabon arrests key figures following coup |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/military-in-gabon-arrests-key-figures-following-coup/2979406 |access-date=31 August 2023 |publisher=Anadolu Agency |language=en |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831135535/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/military-in-gabon-arrests-key-figures-following-coup/2979406 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon: President Ali Bongo under house arrest, according to military putschists |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-president-ali-bongo-under-house-arrest-according-to-military-putschists/ |access-date=30 August 2023 |work=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830122225/https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-president-ali-bongo-under-house-arrest-according-to-military-putschists/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=1 September 2023 |title=Gabon's new strongman threatens business leaders over corruption |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/01/gabons-new-strongman-threatens-business-leaders-over-corruption/ |access-date=1 September 2023 |work=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=2 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230902043401/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/01/gabons-new-strongman-threatens-business-leaders-over-corruption/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Despite his detention, Bongo released a video on social media in which he appeared distressed while pleading for help in English, claiming that he was being held separately from his family while calling on his friends and supporters both in Gabon and around the world to "raise their voice" and "make noise" in response to the coup. Following his appeal, the CEO of a communications firm that helped Bongo during the election said that the military seized the phones of those who were with Bongo.

references.text: <ref name="bbc"/><ref>{{Cite news |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon coup: Ali Bongo calls for help in video, says "I don't know what is going on" |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-coup-ali-bongo-calls-for-help-in-video-says-i-dont-know-what-is-going-on/ |access-date=30 August 2023 |work=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830192404/https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/30/gabon-coup-ali-bongo-calls-for-help-in-video-says-i-dont-know-what-is-going-on/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=31 August 2023 |title=Gabon's mutinous soldiers announce new leader |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/31/gabons-mutinous-soldiers-announce-new-leader/ |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831133652/https://www.africanews.com/2023/08/31/gabons-mutinous-soldiers-announce-new-leader/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

content.title: Proclamation of Brice Oligui as interim president

sentences.text: Brigadier general Brice Clotaire Oligui Nguema|Brice Oligui, commander of the Gabonese Republican Guard|Republican Guard, was later installed as interim president by the military junta, and was seen on the shoulders of jubilant army personnel calling him the "President of Gabon|president". Oligui promised that the dissolution of state institutions would be only be temporary, pending their reconfiguration into more democratic ones.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=Qui est Brice Clotaire Oligui Nguema, le Général à la tête de la transition gabonaise ? |url=https://camerounactuel.com/qui-est-brice-clotaire-oligui-nguema-le-general-a-la-tete-de-la-transition-gabonaise/ |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=fr-FR |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830192404/https://camerounactuel.com/qui-est-brice-clotaire-oligui-nguema-le-general-a-la-tete-de-la-transition-gabonaise/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="cnn"/> In an interview with ''Le Monde'', he referred to Bongo as "retired", and said that the military had staged the coup due to discontent that had been growing in the country since Bongo's stroke in 2018, his decision to run for a third term, the disregarding of the country's Constitution of Gabon|constitution and the conduct of the election.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Bensimon |first=Cyril |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon's coup-leading general says President Bongo has been 'retired' |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/en/le-monde-africa/article/2023/08/30/gabon-s-coup-leading-general-says-bongo-is-retired_6115749_124.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830123104/https://www.lemonde.fr/en/le-monde-africa/article/2023/08/30/gabon-s-coup-leading-general-says-bongo-is-retired_6115749_124.html |archive-date=30 August 2023 |access-date=30 August 2023 |work=Le Monde |language=en}}</ref>

<ref name="family"/> He also said that the military would move "quickly but surely" to avoid elections that "repeat the same mistakes" by keeping the same people in power.<ref name="tempo">{{Cite news |last=Gregory |first=James |date=2 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup: Military chief says suspension of democracy only 'temporary' |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66691766 |access-date=2 September 2023 |publisher=BBC News |language=en |archive-date=2 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230902002009/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66691766 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Oligui's appointment as interim president was confirmed by other generals, and he was formally sworn in as "transitional president" in a ceremony at the Presidential Palace on 4 September. In his inaugural address, he pledged to hold "free, transparent" elections but did not give an exact date as to when, and expressed surprise at international criticism of the coup. He also proposed new electoral legislation, a new penal code, a referendum on a new constitution, and the release of all political prisoners. Among the attendees who arrived were former ministers of Bongo's regime, who were booed by a civilian crowd supporting the junta.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Wright |first=George |date=31 August 2023 |title=Gabon coup leaders name General Brice Oligui Nguema as new leader |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66666585 |access-date=31 August 2023 |publisher=BBC News |language=en |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831010153/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66666585 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=4 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup leader Brice Nguema sworn in as president |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66705693 |access-date=4 September 2023 |publisher=BBC |language=en |archive-date=4 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230904220628/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66705693 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Naadi |first=Thomas |date=4 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup leader Brice Nguema vows free elections – but no date |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66705693 |access-date=5 September 2023 |publisher=BBC |language=en |archive-date=4 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230904220628/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66705693 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 7 September, Oligui reappointed Raymond Ndong Sima, who formerly served as Prime Minister of Gabon|prime minister under Ali Bongo before joining the opposition, to head a transitional government comprising personalities from all sides of the political spectrum. In an interview by the BBC, Ndong Sima said he expected elections to be held within two years and ruled out putting Bongo on trial for corruption. On 9 September, he announced the final composition of his cabinet, which included both critics and figures associated with the Bongo regime, military officials and civil society members but excluded members of the Alternance 2023 coalition which fielded Albert Ondo Ossa in the annulled presidential election.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=7 September 2023 |title=Gabon junta appoints former Bongo ally transitional prime minister |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/07/gabon-junta-appoints-former-bongo-ally-transitional-prime-minister/ |access-date=8 September 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=8 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908021537/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/07/gabon-junta-appoints-former-bongo-ally-transitional-prime-minister/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Jordan |first=Dearbail |date=9 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup: New PM tells BBC country should hold elections within two years |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66752267 |access-date=9 September 2023 |publisher=BBC |language=en |archive-date=8 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908203108/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66752267 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=10 September 2023 |title=Gabon: PM unveils transitional government officials |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/10/gabon-pm-unveils-transitional-government-officials/ |access-date=10 September 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=12 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230912063128/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/10/gabon-pm-unveils-transitional-government-officials/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 11 September, Oligui appointed opposition politician Paulette Missambo to head a transitional Senate of Gabon|Senate. At the same time, he appointed Jean-François Ndongou, a former minister under both Omar and Ali Bongo, to head the transitional National Assembly.

references.text: <ref name="parliament">{{Cite news |date=12 September 2023 |title=Gabon: ex-opposition and former pro-Bongo at the head of Parliament |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/12/gabon-ex-opposition-and-former-pro-bongo-at-the-head-of-parliament/ |access-date=13 September 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=12 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230912213425/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/12/gabon-ex-opposition-and-former-pro-bongo-at-the-head-of-parliament/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 13 November, the new government announced that elections for the presidency and the legislature would be held in August 2025. The military government published a transition timetable to be approved in a "national conference" in April 2024, with the timetable including events such as a referendum to adopt a new constitution.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=13 November 2023 |title=Gabon: military authorities announce elections for August 2025 |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/11/13/gabon-military-authorities-announce-elections-for-august-2025/ |access-date=14 November 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=18 November 2023 |title=Gabon: transition timetable Sparks Debate |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/11/18/gabon-transition-timetable-sparks-debate/ |access-date=10 January 2024 |publisher=Africanews |language=en }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 6 September, the junta announced that Oligui had authorized the release of Ali Bongo on medical grounds, saying that he was free to leave the country for treatment. Following his release, Bongo moved to his private residence in Libreville. In September 2024, Bongo announced his retirement from politics, while appealing for the release of his wife Sylvia and son Noureddin. He also accepted "sole responsibility" for "failings" under his regime. In November 2024, a 2024 Gabonese constitutional referendum|referendum on a new constitution was held, with 91.64% of voters voting to approve it.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=7 September 2023 |title=Gabon's military says ex-president Ali Bongo 'free' to travel abroad |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/7/gabons-military-says-ex-president-ali-bongo-free-to-travel-abroad |access-date=7 September 2023 |publisher=Aljazeera |language=en |archive-date=7 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230907172241/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/7/gabons-military-says-ex-president-ali-bongo-free-to-travel-abroad |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=14 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup: Can Gen Ngeuma usher in a new era? |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66745738 |access-date=14 September 2023 |publisher=BBC |language=en |archive-date=14 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230914002102/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66745738 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=19 September 2024 |title=Gabon's ousted leader Bongo says renouncing politics for good |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240919-gabon-s-ousted-leader-bongo-says-renouncing-politics-for-good |access-date=19 September 2024 |publisher=France 24 |language=en }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-10-18 |title=Journal de l'Afrique - Nouvelle constitution au Gabon, le référendum fixé au 16 novembre |url=https://www.france24.com/fr/%C3%A9missions/journal-de-l-afrique/20241018-nouvelle-constitution-au-gabon-le-r%C3%A9f%C3%A9rendum-fix%C3%A9-au-16-novembre-prochain |access-date=2024-10-22 |website=France 24 |language=fr}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-11-18 |title=Référendum 2024 au Gabon : La nouvelle constitution approuvée avec 91,80 % du Oui |url=https://fr.infosgabon.com/referendum-2024-au-gabon-la-nouvelle-constitution-approuvee-avec-9180-du-oui/ |access-date=2024-11-18 |website=INFOS GABON |language=fr-FR}}</ref>

sentences.text: Following the announcement of the coup, celebrations broke out in the streets of Libreville and in other cities across the country.

references.text: <ref name="bbc"/> The Port of Libreville suspended operations.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dixon |first=Gary |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon closes shipping down after post-election coup |url=https://www.tradewindsnews.com/tankers/gabon-closes-shipping-down-after-post-election-coup/2-1-1508612 |access-date=30 August 2023 |website=TradeWinds |language=en |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830192405/https://www.tradewindsnews.com/tankers/gabon-closes-shipping-down-after-post-election-coup/2-1-1508612?zephr_sso_ott=SN87bK |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: A spokesman for the opposition Alternance 2023 coalition thanked the army for standing up to an "electoral coup d'etat" without bloodshed and called on it to finish counting the results of the annulled election and formally recognize the victory of its candidate, Albert Ondo Ossa, adding that it had invited the security forces to take part in discussions "to work out the situation within a patriotic and responsible framework". However, Ondo Ossa himself criticized the coup, calling it "a disappointment", a "family affair" and a "Coup d'état#Palace coup|palace revolution", claiming that it had been orchestrated by Ali Bongo's estranged sister Pascaline Bongo and noting that it was led by Oligui, who was also Bongo's cousin. In conjunction with the election, he called the recent events "two coups in one", while continuing to assert himself as the winner in the election. Alternance 2023 later called Oligui's inauguration as transitional president "absurd" However, after meeting with Oligui on 5 September, Ondo Ossa called on citizens in an online post "to believe in a better and brighter future" for Gabon.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=31 August 2023 |title=Gabon Opposition Urges Coup Leaders To Recognise It Won Election |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/gabon-opposition-urges-coup-leaders-to-recognise-it-won-election-e1f0a26e |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Barron’s |agency=Agence France-Presse |language=en |archive-date=1 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230901233535/https://www.barrons.com/news/gabon-opposition-urges-coup-leaders-to-recognise-it-won-election-e1f0a26e |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="family">{{Cite web |date=1 September 2023 |title='Family affair': Gabon opposition lambasts coup, claims election victory |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/1/family-affair-gabon-opposition-lambasts-coup-claims-election-victory |access-date=1 September 2023 |publisher=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=1 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230901191350/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/1/family-affair-gabon-opposition-lambasts-coup-claims-election-victory |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=1 September 2023 |title=Gabon's opposition leader claims coup is a 'family affair' |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/01/gabons-opposition-leader-claims-coup-is-a-family-affair/ |access-date=1 September 2023 |publisher=Africanews |language=en |archive-date=2 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230902043404/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/01/gabons-opposition-leader-claims-coup-is-a-family-affair/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="tempo"/> and called on the international community to push the military into restoring civilian rule.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2 September 2023 |title=Gabon coup will not end rule by Bongo clan – presidential source |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66693997 |access-date=3 September 2023 |publisher=BBC News |language=en |archive-date=2 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230902224604/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-66693997 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Obangome |first1=Wilfried |title=Central African Republic president meets Gabon junta leader for talks |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/central-african-republic-president-meets-gabon-junta-leader-talks-2023-09-05/ |access-date=9 September 2023 |work=Reuters |agency=Reuters |publisher=Thomson Reuters |date=5 September 2023 |language=en |archive-date=5 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230905220130/https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/central-african-republic-president-meets-gabon-junta-leader-talks-2023-09-05/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text:
<!-- PLEASE DO NOT INCLUDE STANDARD OPERATING PLATITUDES OF MONITORING THE SITUATION. EVERY COUNTRY DOES THAT. AND PLEASE MAKE SURE TO REPHRASE INFO IN SUCH A WAY THAT IT IS NOT DIRECTLY COPIED FROM A NEWSPAPER. AND NO FLAG OR BULLET SOUP PLEASE -->
Moussa Faki, the Chairperson of the African Union Commission|head of the African Union Commission, condemned the coup and called on Gabon's security forces to "adhere strictly to their republican vocation" and guarantee the safety of Bongo, his family, and members of his government. The bloc suspended Gabon's membership on 31 August. ECOWAS also condemned the coup, with regional power Nigeria expressing alarm over "contagious autocracy" following similar events in the region. It also suspended Gabon's membership in the bloc on 5 September and moved its headquarters from Libreville to Malabo, Equatorial Guinea. It later designated Central African Republic President Faustin Archange Touadera to mediate with Oligui, during which the two sides agreed to draft a roadmap towards the restoration of democracy.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=African Union 'Strongly Condemns Attempted Coup' In Gabon |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/african-union-strongly-condemns-attempted-coup-in-gabon-3794c2ba |access-date=30 August 2023 |work=Barron's |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831033103/https://www.barrons.com/news/african-union-strongly-condemns-attempted-coup-in-gabon-3794c2ba |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/gabon-awaits-next-move-junta-after-coup-ousts-president-bongo-2023-08-31/|title=African Union suspends Gabon's membership after military coup|publisher=Reuters|date=31 August 2023|access-date=31 August 2023|archive-date=31 August 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831091638/https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/gabon-awaits-next-move-junta-after-coup-ousts-president-bongo-2023-08-31/|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="flawed"/> The Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) also condemned the military use of force and asked for restoration of constitutional order,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/gabon-security-eccas-idAFJ8N39H00G |title=Central African bloc calls for return to constitutional order in Gabon |publisher=Reuters |date=31 August 2023 |access-date=1 September 2023 |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831195139/https://www.reuters.com/article/gabon-security-eccas-idAFJ8N39H00G |url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/05/central-african-bloc-suspends-gabon-over-coup/ |title=Central African bloc suspends Gabon over coup |publisher=Africanews |date=5 September 2023 |access-date=5 September 2023 |archive-date=5 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230905164131/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/05/central-african-bloc-suspends-gabon-over-coup/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/07/gabon-region-agree-to-draft-roadmap-for-return-to-democracy/ |title=Gabon, region agree to draft 'roadmap' for return to democracy |publisher=Africanews |date=8 September 2023 |access-date=8 September 2023 |archive-date=8 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908021536/https://www.africanews.com/2023/09/07/gabon-region-agree-to-draft-roadmap-for-return-to-democracy/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy|European Union's foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said the coup would increase instability in Africa, calling it a "big issue for Europe". Patricia Scotland, Commonwealth Secretary-General|secretary-general of the Commonwealth of Nations, which Gabon joined in 2022, reiterated that the organization's charter clearly stated that "member states must uphold the rule of law and the principles of democracy at all times." United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres condemned the coup as a means to resolve the "post-electoral crisis" in Gabon. He later sent his special envoy to Central Africa, Abdou Abarry, to meet with Oligui on 6 September, during which Abarry told him that the UN would assist Gabon as it made a new start.

references.text: <ref name="bbc"/> He later condemned the coup, but acknowledged that the preceding election had been marred with irregularities and was an "institutional coup", calling the vote "stolen".<ref name="flawed">{{cite web |date=31 August 2023 |title=EU's Borrell Says Gabon Coup Followed Flawed Election |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/eu-s-borrell-says-gabon-coup-followed-flawed-election-5873d9e1 |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Barron's |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831135942/https://www.barrons.com/news/eu-s-borrell-says-gabon-coup-followed-flawed-election-5873d9e1 |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="lemonde">{{cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon coup: President Bongo, under 'house arrest,' calls for 'friends' to 'make noise' |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2023/08/30/gabon-soldiers-announce-cancellation-of-election-dissolution-of-institutions_6115190_4.html |access-date=30 August 2023 |work=Le Monde |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830192406/https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2023/08/30/gabon-soldiers-announce-cancellation-of-election-dissolution-of-institutions_6115190_4.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="react">{{cite web |date=31 August 2023 |title=World reaction to the military coup in Gabon |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/8/30/world-reaction-to-the-military-coup-in-gabon |access-date=31 August 2023 |publisher=Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831010031/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/8/30/world-reaction-to-the-military-coup-in-gabon |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=7 September 2023 |title=Gabon military government appoints former opposition leader as interim PM |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/7/gabon-military-government-appoints-former-opposition-leader-as-interim-pm |access-date=8 September 2023 |publisher=Aljazeera |language=en |archive-date=7 September 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230907220340/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/7/gabon-military-government-appoints-former-opposition-leader-as-interim-pm |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Government of France|French government spokesperson Olivier Véran condemned the coup and called for the results of the annulled election to be respected. Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin called for "relevant sides in Gabon to resolve differences peacefully through dialogue", and for ensuring President Bongo's safety is guaranteed. The United States, while formally not referring to the events in Gabon as a "coup", called on "those responsible" for the takeover to "preserve civilian rule." The US Embassy in Gabon advised its citizens to avoid downtown Libreville and areas near the Presidential Palace (Gabon)|Presidential Palace. On 26 September, the State Department announced that it was suspending several assistance programs to Gabon in response to the coup, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken calling the events an "unconstitutional intervention by members of the country’s military”. Canada also called for a "quick, peaceful" return to democratic and civilian-led rule, while Spain|Spanish Defence Minister Margarita Robles said the country would evaluate its involvement in peacekeeping missions in Africa.<ref name="react"/>

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=France Condemns 'Coup Which Is Underway' In Gabon: Govt Spokesman |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/france-condemns-coup-which-is-underway-in-gabon-govt-spokesman-8dfff69f |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Barron's |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830105130/https://www.barrons.com/news/france-condemns-coup-which-is-underway-in-gabon-govt-spokesman-8dfff69f |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=China urges relevant sides in Gabon to resolve differences peacefully through dialogue |url=https://english.news.cn/20230830/83e84d80057644df9c3d1aff42285026/c.html |access-date=30 August 2023 |agency=Xinhua News Agency |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830192416/https://english.news.cn/20230830/83e84d80057644df9c3d1aff42285026/c.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref name="africa1" /> The United Kingdom condemned the coup, calling it "unconstitutional", but also acknowledged flaws during the election.<ref>{{cite web |date=31 August 2023 |title=Britain Condemns 'Unconstitutional' Military Coup In Gabon |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/britain-condemns-unconstitutional-military-coup-in-gabon-b65dd5c0?refsec=topics_afp-news |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Barron's |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831150206/https://www.barrons.com/news/britain-condemns-unconstitutional-military-coup-in-gabon-b65dd5c0?refsec=topics_afp-news |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |date=27 September 2023 |title=US halts foreign assistance to Gabon after August 30 coup |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/27/us-halts-foreign-assistance-to-gabon-after-august-30-coup |access-date=27 September 2023 |publisher=Al Jazeera English|Aljazeera }}</ref>

sentences.text: The French mining firm Eramet, which operates the world's largest manganese mines at Moanda, Gabon|Moanda and has 8,000 employees in Gabon, said it was halting all work in the country for security reasons.

references.text: <ref name="lemonde"/> Eramet shares fell 18% on the morning of the coup.<ref>{{Cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=What could the market impact be from Gabon's coup? |url=https://news.yahoo.com/could-market-impact-gabons-coup-151148213.html |access-date=30 August 2023 |website=Yahoo! News |agency=Reuters |language=en-US |archive-date=30 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830161038/https://news.yahoo.com/could-market-impact-gabons-coup-151148213.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The coup was also seen to have prompted internal reactions from other countries in Africa. In neighbouring Cameroon, President Paul Biya reshuffled the country's military leadership, while Rwandan President Paul Kagame "accepted the resignation" of a dozen generals and more than 80 other senior military officers.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=Gabon election results were a 'smokescreen' for soldiers to oust unpopular president, analysts say |url=https://apnews.com/article/gabon-mutiny-president-bongo-bf34a2f16ab2a3a406270b3a735ef78f |access-date=30 August 2023 |publisher=Associated Press |first=Sam |last=Mednick |language=en-US |archive-date=31 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831082727/https://apnews.com/article/gabon-mutiny-president-bongo-bf34a2f16ab2a3a406270b3a735ef78f |url-status=live }}</ref>
